The Lamé (or ellipsoidal) wave equation is given by \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+(h-\nu(\nu+1)k^{2}{\operatorname{ sn}^{2}}\left(z,k\right)+k^{2}\omega^{2}{\operatorname{sn}^{4}}\left(z,k\right ))w=0, in which \omega is another parameter.
In the case \omega=0 , (LABEL:eq:LA.LW.DE) reduces to Lamé’s equation (LABEL:eq:LA.DE.LE).
For properties of the solutions of (LABEL:eq:LA.LW.DE) see ( ) , ( , Chapter X) , ( , §16.14) , ( ) , and ( ) .
Throughout §§LABEL:sec:LA.D2–LABEL:sec:LA.A2 the order \nu in the differential equation (LABEL:eq:LA.DE.LE) is assumed to be a nonnegative integer.

There are eight types of Lamé polynomials, defined as follows: \mathit{uE}^{m}_{2n}\left(z,k^{2}\right)=\mathit{Ec}^{2m}_{2n}\left(z,k^{2} \right), , \mathit{sE}^{m}_{2n+1}\left(z,k^{2}\right)=\mathit{Ec}^{2m+1}_{2n+1}\left(z,k^ {2}\right), , \mathit{cE}^{m}_{2n+1}\left(z,k^{2}\right)=\mathit{Es}^{2m+1}_{2n+1}\left(z,k^ {2}\right), , \mathit{dE}^{m}_{2n+1}\left(z,k^{2}\right)=\mathit{Ec}^{2m}_{2n+1}\left(z,k^{2 }\right), , \mathit{scE}^{m}_{2n+2}\left(z,k^{2}\right)=\mathit{Es}^{2m+2}_{2n+2}\left(z,k ^{2}\right), , \mathit{sdE}^{m}_{2n+2}\left(z,k^{2}\right)=\mathit{Ec}^{2m+1}_{2n+2}\left(z,k ^{2}\right), , \mathit{cdE}^{m}_{2n+2}\left(z,k^{2}\right)=\mathit{Es}^{2m+1}_{2n+2}\left(z,k ^{2}\right), , \mathit{scdE}^{m}_{2n+3}\left(z,k^{2}\right)=\mathit{Es}^{2m+2}_{2n+3}\left(z, k^{2}\right), where n=0,1,2,\dots , m=0,1,2,\dots,n.
These functions are polynomials in \operatorname{sn}\left(z,k\right) , \operatorname{cn}\left(z,k\right) , and \operatorname{dn}\left(z,k\right).
In consequence they are doubly-periodic meromorphic functions of z.

The superscript m on the left-hand sides of (LABEL:eq:LA.D2.C1)–(LABEL:eq:LA.D2.C8) agrees with the number of z -zeros of each Lamé polynomial in the interval (0,\!K\! ), while n-m is the number of z -zeros in the open line segment from \!K\!
to \!K\!+\mathrm{i}\!{K^{\prime}}\!

The prefixes \mathit{u} , \mathit{s} , \mathit{c} , \mathit{d} , \mathit{sc} , \mathit{sd} , \mathit{cd} , \mathit{scd} indicate the type of the polynomial form of the Lamé polynomial; compare the 3rd and 4th columns in Table LABEL:tab:LA.LP.ET.

In the fourth column the variable z and modulus k of the Jacobian elliptic functions have been suppressed, and P({\operatorname{sn}^{2}}) denotes a polynomial of degree n in {\operatorname{sn}^{2}}\left(z,k\right) (different for each type).
For the determination of the coefficients of the P ’s see §LABEL:sec:LA.F2.CL.

With the substitution \xi={\operatorname{sn}^{2}}\left(z,k\right) every Lamé polynomial in Table LABEL:tab:LA.LP.ET can be written in the form \xi^{\rho}(\xi-1)^{\sigma}(\xi-k^{-2})^{\tau}P(\xi), where \rho , \sigma , \tau are either 0 or \frac{1}{2}.
The polynomial P(\xi) is of degree n and has m zeros (all simple) in (0,1) and n-m zeros (all simple) in (1,k^{-2}).
The functions (LABEL:eq:LA.D2.KA) satisfy (LABEL:eq:LA.DE.F1).
Let \xi_{1},\xi_{2},\dots,\xi_{n} denote the zeros of the polynomial P in ( LABEL:eq:LA.D2.KA) arranged according to 0<\xi_{1}<\cdots<\xi_{m}<1<\xi_{m+1}<\cdots<\xi_{n}<k^{-2}.

Then the function g(t_{1},t_{2},\dots,t_{n})=\left(\prod_{p=1}^{n}t_{p}^{\rho+\frac{1}{4}}|t_{p} -1|^{\sigma+\frac{1}{4}}(k^{-2}-t_{p})^{\tau+\frac{1}{4}}\right)\prod_{q<r}(t_ {r}-t_{q}), defined for (t_{1},t_{2},\dots,t_{n}) with 0\leq t_{1}\leq\cdots\leq t_{m}\leq 1\leq t_{m+1}\leq\cdots\leq t_{n}\leq k^{- 2}, attains its absolute maximum iff t_{j}=\xi_{j} , j=1,2,\dots,n.

Moreover, {\frac{\rho+\frac{1}{4}}{\xi_{p}}+\frac{\sigma+\frac{1}{4}}{\xi_{p}-1}+\frac{ \tau+\frac{1}{4}}{\xi_{p}-k^{-2}}+\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}q=1\\ q\neq p\end{subarray}}^{n}\frac{1}{\xi_{p}-\xi_{q}}=0}, subject to p=1,2,\dots,n.

This result admits the following electrostatic interpretation: Given threepoint masses fixed at t=0 , t=1 , and t=k^{-2} with positive charges \rho+\tfrac{1}{4} , \sigma+\tfrac{1}{4} , and \tau+\tfrac{1}{4} , respectively, and n movable point masses at t_{1},t_{2},\dots,t_{n} arranged according to (LABEL:eq:LA.D2.TT) with unit positive charges, the equilibrium position is attained when t_{j}=\xi_{j} for j=1,2,\dots,n.

para.sentence: Lamé polynomials are orthogonal in two ways.
First, the orthogonality relations (LABEL:eq:LA.DF.O) apply; see §LABEL:sec:LA.D2.EF.

Secondly, the system of functions f_{n}^{m}(s,t)=\mathit{uE}^{m}_{2n}\left(s,k^{2}\right)\mathit{uE}^{m}_{2n} \left(\!K\!+\mathrm{i}t,k^{2}\right), subject to n=0,1,2,\dots, m=0,1,\dots,n, is orthogonal and complete with respect to the inner product \langle g,h\rangle=\int_{0}^{\!K\!}\!\!\int_{0}^{\!{K^{\prime}}\!}w(s,t)g(s,t) h(s,t)\mathrm{d}t\mathrm{d}s, where w(s,t)={\operatorname{sn}^{2}}\left(\!K\!+\mathrm{i}t,k\right)-{\operatorname{ sn}^{2}}\left(s,k\right).

Each of the following seven systems is orthogonal and complete with respect to the inner product (LABEL:eq:LA.OR.IP): \mathit{sE}^{m}_{2n+1}\left(s,k^{2}\right)\mathit{sE}^{m}_{2n+1}\left(\!K\!+ \mathrm{i}t,k^{2}\right), , \mathit{cE}^{m}_{2n+1}\left(s,k^{2}\right)\mathit{cE}^{m}_{2n+1}\left(\!K\!+ \mathrm{i}t,k^{2}\right), , \mathit{dE}^{m}_{2n+1}\left(s,k^{2}\right)\mathit{dE}^{m}_{2n+1}\left(\!K\!+ \mathrm{i}t,k^{2}\right), , \mathit{scE}^{m}_{2n+2}\left(s,k^{2}\right)\mathit{scE}^{m}_{2n+2}\left(\!K\!+ \mathrm{i}t,k^{2}\right), , \mathit{sdE}^{m}_{2n+2}\left(s,k^{2}\right)\mathit{sdE}^{m}_{2n+2}\left(\!K\!+ \mathrm{i}t,k^{2}\right), , \mathit{cdE}^{m}_{2n+2}\left(s,k^{2}\right)\mathit{cdE}^{m}_{2n+2}\left(\!K\!+ \mathrm{i}t,k^{2}\right), , \mathit{scdE}^{m}_{2n+3}\left(s,k^{2}\right)\mathit{scdE}^{m}_{2n+3}\left(\!K \!+\mathrm{i}t,k^{2}\right).
In each system n ranges over all nonnegative integers and m=0,1,\dots,n.

When combined, all eight systems (LABEL:eq:LA.OR.S1) and (LABEL:eq:LA.OR.S2)–(LABEL:eq:LA.OR.S8) form an orthogonal and complete system with respect to the inner product \langle g,h\rangle=\int_{0}^{4\!K\!}\!\!\int_{0}^{2\!{K^{\prime}}\!}w(s,t)g(s, t)h(s,t)\mathrm{d}t\mathrm{d}s, with w(s,t) given by (LABEL:eq:LA.OR.WE).

A second approach is to solve the continued-fraction equations typified by (LABEL:eq:LA.DF.CF) by Newton’s rule or other iterative methods; see §LABEL:sec:NM.NLE. Initial approximations to the eigenvalues can be found, for example, from the asymptotic expansions supplied in §LABEL:sec:LA.A1.EV.

Subsequently, formulas typified by (LABEL:eq:LA.F1.AE3) can be applied to compute the coefficients of the Fourier expansions of the corresponding Lamé functions by backward recursion followed by application of formulas typified by (LABEL:eq:LA.F1.AE4) and (LABEL:eq:LA.F1.AE5) to achieve normalization; compare §LABEL:sec:NM.LDE. (Equation (LABEL:eq:LA.F1.AE2) serves as a check.)The Fourier series may be summed using Clenshaw’s algorithm; see §LABEL:sec:NM.APT.CHEB.
For further information see ( ) .

A third method is to approximate eigenvalues and Fourier coefficients of Lamé functions by eigenvalues and eigenvectors of finite matrices using the methods of §§LABEL:sec:NM.LIN.LANCZS and LABEL:sec:NM.NLE.POLEQ.
These matrices are the same as those provided in §LABEL:sec:LA.F2.DC for the computation of Lamé polynomials with the difference that n has to be chosen sufficiently large.
The approximations converge geometrically (§LABEL:sec:NM.NLE.INT) to the eigenvalues and coefficients of Lamé functions as n\to\infty.
The numerical computations described in ( ) are based in part upon this method.
A fourth method is by asymptotic approximations by zeros of orthogonal polynomials of increasing degree.
See (f) of §LABEL:sec:MA.CO.CV.

The eigenvalues corresponding to Lamé polynomials are computed from eigenvalues of the finite tridiagonal matrices \mathbf{M} given in §LABEL:sec:LA.F2.DC, using methods described in §LABEL:sec:NM.LIN.LANCZS and ( ) .
The corresponding eigenvectors yield the coefficients in the finite Fourier series for Lamé polynomials.
§LABEL:sec:LA.F2.DC includes formulas for normalizing the eigenvectors.

Zeros of Lamé polynomials can be computed by solving the system of equations (LABEL:eq:LA.D2.ZE) by employing Newton’s method; see §LABEL:sec:NM.NLE.NEWTON. Alternatively, the zeros can be found by locating the maximum of function g in (LABEL:eq:LA.D2.DH).
Precision is 4D.
